The {{nihongo|'''28 cm Howitzer L/10'''|二十八糎榴弾砲|nijūhachi-senchi ryūdanhō}} was a [[Imperial Japanese Army|Japanese]] [[Coastal artillery|coastal]] and [[siege engine|siege]] [[howitzer]]. It was developed by [[Krupp]] before 1892 and saw service in the [[Russo-Japanese War]] during the [[siege of Port Arthur]] and the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]].
==Design and description== The ''28 cm Howitzer L/10'' was a design of [[Krupp]] but some 220 pieces were manufactured by the Osaka Artillery Arsenal for Japanese coastal defence.<ref>[http://www3.plala.or.jp/takihome/28cm.htm Website about IJA 28 cm Howitzer]</ref> It was mounted on a turntable which was fixed to a steel firing platform. It required two to four days to emplace for firing. An ammunition crane was fixed to the carriage for ease of loading as can be seen in the image above. The howitzer entered service in 1892 and was installed in shore batteries in forts overlooking [[Tokyo Bay]] and [[Osaka Bay]], and had been intended for anti-ship operations. However it saw use as a siege gun during the Russo-Japanese War due to the lack of heavy siege guns.
It fired a {{convert|217|kg|lb|abbr=on}} [[high-explosive]] shell to a range of {{convert|7800|m|yd}}.<ref name=h>Kowner, p. 151</ref>
==Combat history==
===Russo-Japanese War=== [[File:Japanese 11 inch siege gun shells Port Stanley 1904.jpg|thumb|left|A shell, visible above the smoke, is fired on Port Arthur.]] During the Russo-Japanese War the [[Third Army (Japan)|Japanese Third Army]] was [[Siege of Port Arthur|besieging Port Arthur]]. While the capture of Port Arthur had been achieved in a single assault during the [[First Sino-Japanese War]] the situation was different in 1904. The Russians had been in possession of Port Arthur since 1897 and had constructed strong fortifications around the city following the plans of [[General]] [[Eduard Totleben]]. After the first general assault in August 1904 and over 16,000 casualties General [[Nogi Maresuke|Nogi]], the commanding officer of the Japanese forces, requested heavy siege guns. With the arrival of the first battery of 28 cm howitzers, replacing those lost when the transport ''[[Hitachi Maru]]'', loaded with a battalion of the First Reserve Regiment of the Guards, was sunk by Russian cruisers in the [[Hitachi Maru Incident]] on June 15, 1904 the situation changed. The massive 11-inch howitzers could throw a 217 kilogram (478 pound) shell over 7.8 kilometers (4.8 miles), and Nogi at last had the firepower necessary to make a serious attempt against the Russian fortifications. The huge shells were nicknamed "roaring trains" by the Russian troops (for the sound they made just before impact), and during their period at Port Arthur over 16,949 of these shells were fired.<ref>[http://www3.plala.or.jp/takihome/artillery_history.html Website about The History of Battles of Imperial Japanese Artillery Forces]</ref>
[[File:28cm Howitzer japan 01.JPG|thumb|A 217 kilogram (478 pound) shell of the 28 cm Howitzer.]] [[File:-Port Arthur viewed from the Top of the 203 Meter Hill.jpg|thumb|Port Arthur viewed from the Top of the 203 Meter Hill, looking at the ships of the [[Pacific Fleet (Russia)|Russian Pacific Fleet]].]] Finally, at 10:30 on December 5, following another massive artillery bombardment, the Japanese managed to overrun ''203 Meter Hill'' overlooking the harbour of Port Arthur with the [[Pacific Fleet (Russia)|Russian Pacific Fleet]] at anchor. They send [[Artillery observer]] on the hill, directing the fire of the 28 cm howitzer destroying systematically the Russian fleet, one ship after another. On December 5, 1904, the [[battleship]] [[Russian battleship Poltava (1894)|''Poltava'']] was destroyed, followed by the battleship [[Russian battleship Retvizan|''Retvizan'']] on December 7, 1904, the battleships [[Russian battleship Pobeda|''Pobeda'']] and [[Russian battleship Peresvet|''Peresvet'']] and the cruisers [[Russian cruiser Pallada (1899)|''Pallada'']] and [[Russian cruiser Bayan (1900)|''Bayan'']] on December 9, 1904. The battleship [[Russian battleship Sevastopol (1895)|''Sevastopol'']], although hit 5 times by {{convert|11|in|mm|sing=on}} shells, managed to move out of range of the guns. On the night of January 2, 1905, after Port Arthur surrendered, Captain [[Nikolai Essen]] of the ''Sevastopol'' had the crippled battleship scuttled in {{convert|30|fathom|m|lk=on}} of water by opening the sea cocks on one side, so that the ship would sink on its side and could not be raised and salvaged by the Japanese.
===Second Sino-Japanese War=== In November 1939 during the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]] 28 cm howitzers were deployed at the [[Yellow River]] where they put a railway tunnel out of action for over three months.<ref>[http://shanxi.nekoyamada.com/?p=158 Website about IJA 28 cm howitzer in the Second Sino-Japanese War]</ref>
===World War II=== Due to a lack of alternatives the Japanese reactivated the 28 cm howitzer for coastal defence in 1945, expecting the landing of the [[Allies]]. 13 guns were in use on [[Kyushu]], 6 on [[Shikoku]], 62 on [[Honshu]] and 10 on [[Hokkaido]].<ref>Zaloga, p. 11</ref> Also, a two batteries of the 28 cm howitzers were used with some success by [[132nd Independent Mixed Brigade (Imperial Japanese Army)|132nd independent mixed brigade]] at [[Dongning, Heilongjiang]] during the [[Soviet invasion of Manchuria]] in 1945.<ref>[http://ibiblio.org/hyperwar/Japan/Monos/pdfs/JM-154/JM-154.pdf Record of Operations against Soviet Russia, Eastern Front (August 1945), p. 60]</ref> Also, 2 batteries of 28 cm howitzers were emplased with [[Najin Fortress Garrison]] in [[Rason]].
